fields.Primary Story Content: Individuals on the autism spectrum have different ways of thinking. Some are photorealistic visual thinkers, others are pattern thinkers who view things spatially, and still others think verbally. And CSU Professor Dr. Temple Grandin says the world needs all these different kinds of minds engaged in solving problems.

College/Division: Walter Scott, Jr. College of Engineering
fields.Primary Story Content: The world runs on water — and Neil Grigg, a civil and environmental engineering professor at CSU, studies how to protect water systems from natural disasters and terrorist attacks. This focus is just the latest aspect of Grigg's critical research; he's been helping to educate and work alongside the world's top water administrators since the 1960s. His research on engineering and management systems for water resources has influenced policy and infrastructure in Colombia, Egypt, Brazil, Somalia, and worldwide.

fields.Primary Story Content:
“The greatest impact is when you can empower others and help them also make an impact. When people have passion and the power to create change, the cycle of impact is collective ... and collective impact is infinite impact.”

Christiana Kennedy wanted to help as many animals as possible, but she knew she couldn’t do it alone. So she started PawsCO, a foster-based animal rescue in Denver, CO, that focuses on supporting the work of rural and urban animal shelters.

All PawsCO animals live in foster homes, rather than shelters, until they are adopted. Today, PawsCO has more than 350 volunteers.

“By sharing my passion to help animals with other people, there have been numerous ripples of empowerment: people who become advocates for animals, people who have fostered and welcomed animals in their own homes, people who have become passionate about adoption and have adopted animals, donated resources, and thought differently about the way they interact with animals.”

Her love for animals also inspires her work for the Colorado State University System, which offers education in human and animal health.

“I like to think of my work as finding challenges and working to solve them in new ways. Whether it's thinking about how to best help animals in need and the shelter partners who serve them, or thinking about new ways that our higher education system can serve students and help them feel like college is a path they can chose -- I've been really fortunate in my roles to be able to think about finding ways to connect identified problems with creative and fresh solutions.”

Tiana and her husband, Matt, enjoy being foster parents and live in Denver with their rescue dog, Poe.

“One day when I look back on my life, I hope the answer remains that my greatest impact is on helping people think a little differently. I try to approach situations with compassion and action, and for whatever my career and life throw at me, I hope that will continue to serve others well.”

“My education at CSU has been the foundation of all that I do. Learning to be a communicator – my liberal arts education – is by far my most important skill set in my career. No matter what I am doing or which problems I'm diving into trying to solve, being able to communicate with others about the issue, share ideas, and outline possible solutions is key.”

For Future Research | Para futuras investigaciones

Learn all you can. Share what you learn. | Aprende todo lo que puedas. Comparte lo que aprendes.

What processes determine whether a storm will produce a large amount of rain in a small area vs. a small amount spread among a large area? How can we improve our forecasting of heavy rain events? Knowing where it is going to rain, for how long, and how hard is the key to understanding everything from agriculture to flooding. And these questions are at the forefront of Dr. Russ Schumacher's work as the Colorado State Climatologist and leader of the CSU-based Colorado Climate Center.

fields.Primary Story Content: Dr. Albert Bimper, Jr., senior associate athletic director for diversity and inclusion and associate professor of ethnic studies at CSU, understands that student-athletes in college often don't see much further than the boundaries of their playing field. Balancing the demands of school and competition keeps many athletes from experiencing some of the best parts of college life — including the chance to study abroad. Bimper, a 2006 CSU graduate who went on to play on the Indianapolis Colts Super Bowl champion team, returned to his alma mater with a goal of promoting diversity and inclusion in Athletics and improving the overall academic experience of student working their way through college as athletes. Bimper created the Green and Global service experience, which takes a group of student-athletes each summer to Petersfield, Jamaica, to stretch their boundaries, immerse themselves in another culture, and learn to better understand their role and connections as global citizens.

fields.Primary Story Content: In today’s data-driven world, global challenges cannot be solved without access to relevant, accurate information — fast. Under the direction of professor and founder Mazdak Arabi, CSU’s One Water Solutions Institute (OWSI) has developed a robust portfolio of cloud-based software and research tools to equip public, private, and nongovernmental entities with world-class research and innovations necessary to address existing and emerging challenges in watershed sustainability and management. fields.Primary Story Content: Most people are familiar with the plight of polar bears affected by climate change, or rhinos affected by poaching, but few are likely familiar with the huemul — the rarest species of deer in the Americas, described as a mix of a kangaroo and a mountain goat in a deer body. Without the same name recognition, animals like the huemul or the saiga (a kind of antelope) or the takin (a member of the camel family) are less likely to receive the funding needed to study the challenges they face and the efforts that could mean the difference between rebound and extinction. Wildlife conservation biologist and CSU researcher Joel Berger advocates for these lesser-known species and one of the world’s preeminent field biologists, and focuses on species in North America, Mongolia, Namibia, and the Arctic.

Biography
Dr. Bhaskar specializes in changes to hydrologic systems from urban development, with a focus on interactions between groundwater, surface water, and engineered stormwater and water distribution systems. Dr. Bhaskar received a Sc.B. in Geology-Physics/Math from Brown University in Providence, Rhode Island, and a Ph.D. in Environmental Engineering from University of Maryland, Baltimore County. She was a graduate trainee of the National Science Foundation Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) in "Water in the Urban Environment" at UMBC. Dr. Bhaskar was then awarded a National Science Foundation Earth Sciences Postdoctoral Fellowship, which took her to the Eastern Geographic Science Center at the U.S. Geological Survey in Reston, Virginia, before joining CSU.

fields.Primary Story Content: Chemistry brought us plastics, and now CSU professor Eugene Chen is using chemistry to save us from these synthetic materials and their unintended environmental impacts. Roughly 56 million tons of plastic trash are overflowing the world's landfills and bobbing in our oceans. By 2050, this means there will be more plastic (by weight) in the oceans than fish. Chen and his research team are creating fully recyclable polymers that can compete with conventional petroleum plastics.

fields.Primary Story Content: After a mosquito takes a bloodmeal from its host, it can be thought of as a small, flying syringe. If we can trap these insects and study the contents of their bloodmeals, we can understand not only which mammal the mosquito took a bloodmeal from but also which infectious diseases they may be carrying. Working in Guatemala, CSU professor Greg Ebel's lab is exploiting these feeding patterns to better characterize which viruses, bacteria, and parasites are circulating in humans and animals.

fields.Primary Story Content: While outdoor air chemistry is a much-studied discipline, the science of indoor air chemistry has been less explored — until recently. Most U.S. residents spend 90% of their time indoors, and the combination of chemicals and products used for everyday household activities like cooking and cleaning can lead to unexpected and potentially harmful airborne chemical compounds. CSU atmospheric chemist Delphine Farmer and her CU collaborator Marina Vance won a Sloan Foundation grant to map the airborne chemistry of a typical home — a first-of-its-kind project dubbed HOMEChem — which will serve as a baseline study of what a person at home, doing typical home activities, can expect to breathe.

fields.Research Focus: Climate change and pastorial livelihoods - Mongolia
fields.Primary Story Content: Rangelands make up three-quarters of Mongolia and are vitally important to the Mongolian people, and important to wildlife populations globally. Since 2008, CSU professor Maria Fernández-Giménez has led the Mongolian Rangelands and Resilience Project, tracking the impacts of ecological and climate change on Mongolia’s traditional herding families and strengthening connections between natural resource science and the country’s policymakers. Fernández-Giménez was awarded the Order of the Polar Star in 2016 — the highest civilian honor Mongolia bestows on foreign nationals.

College/Division: College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
fields.Primary Story Content: Malaria, a preventable and potentially fatal disease transmitted by mosquitos, kills 445,000 people, mostly children, each year. In Burkina Faso, nearly every single person has malaria parasites in his or her system during the rainy season, and children can get the disease repeatedly before they develop immunity. Dr. Brian Foy, a professor in the Department of Microbiology, Immunology and Pathology at CSU, found that the use of Ivermectin, typically used to treat parasitic worms, led to a significant reduction in cases of malaria among children under the age of five. While Ivermectin has been known to kill blood feeding insects like mosquitos, Dr. Foy thinks it may also have an effect on the malaria parasite inside the body. If he's right, the findings could have implications for communities and inviduals across West Africa.

fields.Research Focus: Bat viruses & infectious disease ecology in Uganda
fields.Primary Story Content: Bats, the only mammals with powered flight, are the second-most abundant order of mammals behind rodents and carry an equally impressive assemblage of viruses, many of which can make people sick. In Uganda, Dr. Rebekah Kading's lab studies not only which viruses the bats are infected with, but also how those viruses may be transmitted. By better understanding how these pathogens spread, we can paint a picture of the possible ways humans may be exposed, and how to prevent the next virus outbreak.

fields.Primary Story Content: What we call things matters, and when it comes to streams and small waterways, it can matter a lot. Under the EPA’s recent Navigable Waters Protection Rule, streams classified as “ephemeral streams” — those which only flow briefly after rain or snowmelt — are not protected under the Clean Water Act. With fewer protections, more pollutants can be washed downstream — but some streams classified as ephemeral may actually be intermittent or seasonal, which would qualify them for protection. That’s where CSU professor Dr. Stephanie Kampf comes in. Dr. Kampf has been working for four years to map and define small headwater streams. Kampf and her team recently enlisted the help of the public through the Stream Tracker Project, an app that allows users to collect and submit their own data on nearby waterways.

fields.Primary Story Content: Dr. Jan Leach, associate dean for research and professor of Bioagricultural Sciences and Pest Management in the College of Agricultural Sciences at CSU, combats world hunger one grain of rice at a time. Defending one of the world's most important food crops from the ravages of pests and climate change, driven by a strong sense of purpose in her work, Leach partners closely with rice growers and scientific collaborators in the Philippines and worldwide. She believes collaboration is key to protecting the food that sustains most of the developing world.

Supply chain management is usually used to build up a business, but CSU professor John McDonald wants to use supply chain management to bring down wildlife-destroying criminals. McDonald’s work in Africa is centered in Sri Lanka. Illegal wildlife trafficking generates an estimated $23 billion each year in the worldwide criminal economy. Thriving illegal businesses, just like legal ones, have a steady — and often complicated — integrated flow of purchasing and distribution operations. Disrupting the supply chain can kill the business. Understanding the supply chain of wildlife trafficking may be able to help slow the crime and prosecute criminals.

fields.Primary Story Content: The world’s population is expected to exceed 9 billion by 2050. With this growth will come heightened demand for clean water, healthy food, manufactured goods, and abundant energy — all requiring accelerated natural resource development and extraction. Stephanie Malin, environmental sociology professor and founding member of the Center for Environmental Justice at CSU, researches the impacts and outcomes of energy production and globalization on the health and sustainability of Earth’s finite ecosystems, resources, and communities. In her book, The Price of Nuclear Power: Uranium Communities and Environmental Justice, Malin asks whether nuclear power provides a socially sustainable solution in the age of climate change mitigation, exploring the intersection of legacy uranium mining and current efforts to renew uranium production at sites such as the Piñon Ridge Uranium Mill in western Colorado.

To achieve village-level electrification, the CSU Energy Institute is working with the University of Rwanda to build mirrored microgrid labs at both locations to facilitate continued collaboration between the two institutions.

fields.Primary Story Content: It is not enough to develop a drug to combat disease; scientists must also discover the proper dose. While some of this testing is done on animals, Dr. Brad Reisfeld, professor in the CSU Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, saw a different way — a mathematical approach, modeling biological systems and chemical pathways to better understand the effects of drugs on humans and animals. Dr. Reisfeld's research has been used to optimize dosing for pulmonary tuberculosis, as well as several diseases important in Thailand such as malaria, HIV, and Steven-Johnson Syndrome.

College/Division: College of Veterinary Medicine and Biomedical Sciences
fields.Primary Story Content: The human gut contains tens of trillions of microorganisms, and these bacteria interact intimately with the immune system. The food that we eat impacts which bacteria are present and can ultimately reduce the risk of developing cancer and infectious disease. Dr. Elizabeth Ryan studies one of the world’s most abundant foods — rice — and its potential role in both modulating gut health to reduce disease, and increasing food security in lower- and middle-income countries. Ryan works in many countries but is starting a new project with the International Rice Research Institute in the Philippines, characterizing the way rice byproducts like rice bran can be used to improve global health and food security.

fields.Primary Story Content: Without water, there is no life — and every drop counts. Sybil Sharvelle, Ph.D., associate professor of civil and environmental engineering at CSU, is researching water conservation systems such as graywater and stormwater reuse in urban and arid environments. In 2018, Sharvelle and her team secured a $3 million NSF grant to develop a national traineeship program to train the next generation of scientific leaders “to tackle complex societal programs.” The program — InTERFEWS (Interdisciplinary Training, Education and Research in Food-Energy-Water Systems in Semi-Arid Regions) — taps the skills and interests of Ph.D. students from disparate disciplines to research innovations that foster a more sustainable, waste-free future for all.

fields.Research Focus: International supply chains and illicit trade
fields.Primary Story Content: Underground networks traffic in everything from illegal weapons and drugs to looted antiquities to exotic animal products or even human beings. These networks are often highly technologically sophisticated and operate with impunity across borders, funneling profits to criminal and terrorist organizations, undermining governments, and victimizing marginalized people. CSU engineering professor Steve Simske wants to help put an end to all that. Between 2008-2012, Dr. Simske pioneering a counterfeit image-detection technology at HP. Through added customization and analytic capabilities, Simske hopes this technology can monitor various supply chains and scan for statistically relevant deviations in order to differentiate legitimate and illicit supply chains.

fields.Primary Story Content: All cats — domestic and wild — can become infected with feline immunodeficiency virus (FIV), resulting in a disease process comparable to HIV in humans. CSU veterinarian Dr. Sue VandeWoude’s laboratory studies factors that contribute to FIV transmission and the development and progression of the disease in cats. The ultimate goal of this research is to translate these findings to better understand viruses in humans. Dr. VandeWoude is currently on a Fulbright sabbatical studying wildlife disease ecology in Tasmania.

fields.Primary Story Content: In Antarctica, the frozen ground looks barren – but dig into it, and put it under a microscope, and you’ll see tiny rugged worms, nematodes, that could help unlock our understanding of Earth’s changing climate. CSU professor Diana Wall has been making the voyage to the bottom of the globe every year since 1989 — more than 30 years of studying the life hidden in the Antarctic soil. Exploring the soil, studying the diversity of microbes and invertebrates, can shed light on how human activities around the world affect the health, productivity, and fertility of soils worldwide.

Unit/Program: Energy Institute; Engines & Energy Conversion Laboratory
fields.Primary Story Content: Electric power is scarce in Rwanda, where 1-in-4 people has an electric hookup, a hookup rate that drops to 1-in-10 in rural areas. CSU professor Bryan Willson’s work harnessing the University’s energy expertise to bring clean, affordable energy to Rwanda is just one example of Willson’s 25 years of work in more than 40 countries. The teams in Willson’s research lab, the Engines and Energy Conversion Lab are innovators in world needs like energy production and engine technology, advanced electrical grids, and biofuels. In Rwanda, AC/DC microgrids are powering people’s daily lives and boosting the entire country’s economic wellbeing.

An estimated 100,000 elephants were killed in Africa for the ivory in their tusks and teeth from 2010 to 2012 alone. Elephants are among the slowest-producing mammals in the world; and it could take almost a century for forest elephants to recover from these intense levels of poaching. Despite this pressure, the structure of their social networks has remained remarkably stable. World-renowned elephant expert and CSU associate professor George Wittemeyer has spent his career of more than 20 years tracking elephants. He has tracked more than 1,000 individuals and 70 families to date — studying not only the effects of poaching on elephant populations and their social bonds, but the effects of habitat destruction from railroad, highway, and oil pipeline construction, and the resiliency of elephant communities.

fields.Primary Story Content:
Creating a sense of belonging | Crear un sentido de pertenencia 

Creating a sense of belonging for people from cross-cultural and third-culture backgrounds | Crear un sentido de pertenencia para las personas interculturales y de una tercera cultura. 

Educational Pathway: Journalism and Technical Communications  

Educación: Periodismo y Técnicas de la Comunicación 

Doni Aldine is a globally mobile Afro-Latina and first-generation American who, by age 19, lived in and identified with seven cultures on five continents. As Founder and Editor-in-Chief for ‘Culturs Global Multicultural Magazine’, Aldine is passionate about creating a community for cross-cultural populations. 

Doni Aldine es una afrolatina con movilidad global y estadounidense de primera generación que, a los 19 años, vivió e identificó con siete culturas en los cinco continentes. Como fundadora y editora en jefe de 'Culturs Global Multicultural Magazine', a Aldine le apasiona crear una comunidad para poblaciones interculturales. 

Extensive Global Experience  

She has extensive global experience in communications, media and marketing for organizations both large and emerging. She has presented around the globe as a keynote, at conferences, at major universities and in major media outlets. Aldine also developed university curricula for global culture identity and is a faculty member in Journalism and Media Communication at Colorado State University. 

“My education at Colorado State University prepared me for my career by providing the writing, editing, marketing, and management skills necessary to build a world-class organization.” 

Amplia experiencia mundial 

Tiene una amplia experiencia global en comunicaciones, medios y marketing para organizaciones tanto grandes como emergentes. Se ha presentado en todo el mundo como discurso principal, en conferencias, en las principales universidades y en los principales medios de comunicación. Aldine también desarrolló planes de estudio universitarios para la identidad cultural global y es miembro de la facultad de Periodismo y Comunicación de Medios en la Universidad Estatal de Colorado. 

“Mi educación en la Universidad Estatal de Colorado me preparó para mi carrera al brindarme las habilidades de redacción, edición, mercadeo y administración necesarias para construir una organización de clase mundial”. 

Building community for in-between populations  

Aldine uses media to activate 21st-century cultural diversity for in-between populations like mixed-race, multicultural, multiethnic, and geographically mobile people such as immigrants, refugees, and ‘Third Culture Kid’ people. “Everyone should feel like they matter,” says Aldine. 

Construir comunidad para poblaciones intermedias 

Aldine utiliza los medios para activar la diversidad cultural del siglo XXI para poblaciones intermedias como personas de raza mixta, multiculturales, multiétnicas y geográficamente móviles, como inmigrantes, refugiados y "niños de la tercera cultura". “Todos deberían sentir que importan”, dice Aldine. 

 

“Diversity isn’t always what you think it is," Aldine said. "People bring so many ideas to the table and that’s what this in-between space is; what you see isn’t necessarily what you get. We’ve made assumptions too long based on how people look." 

 

“La diversidad no siempre es lo que crees que es”, dijo Aldine. “La gente trae tantas ideas a la mesa y eso es lo que es este espacio intermedio; lo que ves no es necesariamente lo que hay. Hemos hecho suposiciones durante demasiado tiempo en función de cómo se ve la gente".

fields.en-StoryTitle: A Role Model for Women in Space
fields.Primary Story Content:
Shelli Brunswick  

A role model for women in space | Un modelo a seguir para las mujeres en el espacio 

Shelli Brunswick, COO of Space Foundation, has a distinguished career as a space acquisition, program manager and congressional liaison for the U.S. Air Force. She advocates for space technology innovation and entrepreneurship. In her role, she collaborates with government, commercial and educational sectors on initiatives for space commerce, young professionals, teacher development, and space-inspired curriculum. 

Shelli Brunswick, directora de operaciones de Space Foundation, tiene una carrera distinguida como administradora de programas, coordinadora de adquisiciones espaciales y enlace con el Congreso para la Fuerza Aérea de EE. UU. Aboga por la innovación en tecnología espacial y el espíritu empresarial. En su función, colabora con los sectores gubernamentales, comerciales y educativos en iniciativas para el comercio espacial, los jóvenes profesionales, el desarrollo docente y los planes de estudio inspirados en el espacio. 

Founded in 1983, the Space Foundation is a nonprofit organization that works to provide information, education, and collaboration for space exploration and space-to-Earth industries that define the global space ecosystem.  

Fundada en 1983, Space Foundation es una organización sin fines de lucro que trabaja para proporcionar información, educación y colaboración para la exploración espacial y las industrias del espacio a la Tierra que definen el ecosistema espacial global. 

Brunswick is passionate about giving back to the space community and contributing to the development of a diverse and inclusive workforce. As a leading role model for women in space, Brunswick was selected as the 2020 Diversity and Inclusion Officer and Role Model of the Year by WomenTech Network and a Woman of Influence by the Colorado Springs Business Journal.  

A Brunswick le apasiona apoyar a la comunidad espacial y contribuir al desarrollo de una fuerza laboral diversa e inclusiva. Como modelo a seguir para las mujeres en el espacio, Brunswick fue seleccionada como Oficial de Diversidad e Inclusión y Modelo a Seguir del Año 2020 por WomenTech Network y Mujer de Influencia por Colorado Springs Business Journal. 

Brunswick began her profession in the U.S. Air Force as a high school graduate and continued into a 29-year career as a space acquisition and program management leader, and as a congressional liaison. She graduated summa cum laude with her Bachelor of Science in Business Administration from Colorado State University-Pueblo while establishing her career in the U.S. Air Force. She received her Master of Business Administration from the University of Phoenix. 

Brunswick comenzó su carrera en la Fuerza Aérea de los EE. UU. como graduada de la escuela secundaria y continuó con una carrera de 29 años como líder de administración de programas y adquisiciones espaciales, y como enlace en el Congreso. Se graduó summa cum laude con su Licenciatura en Ciencias en Administración de Empresas de la Universidad Estatal de Colorado-Pueblo mientras establecía su carrera en la Fuerza Aérea de los EE. UU. Recibió su Maestría en Administración de Empresas de la Universidad de Phoenix. 

“CSU-Pueblo has given them the knowledge, skills and ability to navigate the future!”    

"¡CSU-Pueblo les ha dado el conocimiento, las habilidades y la capacidad para navegar el futuro!" 

 

Video How She Got There | Shelli Brunswick, COO of Space Foundation 

Space Force <https://www.spacefoundation.org/human/shelli-brunswick/>

fields.Primary Story Content:
Amplifying underrepresented voices | Amplificar las voces marginadas 

 

Reporting on inequities  

During America’s reckoning with race in 2020, Eugene Daniels moderated POLITICO’s Confronting Inequality Town Hall series which examined how inequities in policing, housing, healthcare, education, and employment are seen across the United States.  

Informar sobre las desigualdades 

Durante la luchas internas de Estados Unidos con su historia y la raza en 2020, Eugene Daniels moderó la serie Confronting Inequality Town Hall de POLITICO, que examinó cómo se ven las desigualdades en la vigilancia, la vivienda, la atención médica, la educación y el empleo en los Estados Unidos. 

 

Daniels is a political reporter and White House correspondent at POLITICO. His work focuses on Vice President Kamala Harris, First Lady Dr. Jill Biden, the Second Gentleman, and emerging power players in Washington. He uses print, video journalism, and podcasts to inform the world of politics, policy, and power.   

Daniels es reportero político y corresponsal en la Casa Blanca de POLITICO. Su trabajo se centra en la vicepresidenta Kamala Harris, la primera dama Dra. Jill Biden, el segundo caballero y los actores de poder emergentes en Washington. Utiliza medios impresos, videoperiodismo y podcasts para informar al mundo de la política, las normas y el poder. 

 

In college, Daniels was a defensive lineman for the Colorado State Rams football team. He injured his shoulder just before his junior season and never played football again. Daniels remained part of the football team but couldn’t compete or fully participate. After his injury, he shifted more of his energy to his television journalism career and into providing his teammates and other student-athletes with a voice within the National Collegiate Athletic Association. In 2012 he became chair of the NCAA Student-Athlete Advisory Committee, where he helped to improve the public perception of his student-athlete peers.  

En la universidad, Daniels fue liniero defensivo del equipo de fútbol americano Colorado State Rams. Se lesionó el hombro justo antes de su tercera temporada y nunca volvió a jugar al fútbol. Daniels siguió siendo parte del equipo de fútbol, pero no pudo competir ni participar plenamente. Después de su lesión, centró su energía más en su carrera de periodismo televisivo y en brindarles a sus compañeros de equipo y otros estudiantes-atletas una voz dentro de la Asociación Nacional de Atletismo Colegiado. En 2012 se convirtió en presidente del Comité Asesor de Estudiantes Atletas de la NCAA, donde ayudó a mejorar la percepción pública de sus compañeros estudiantes atletas. 

 

Daniels graduated from Colorado State University in 2012 with a bachelor's degree in Journalism and Technical Communication with a focus on Political Science. Since college, Daniels has built a career around amplifying underrepresented voices.  

Daniels se graduó de la Universidad Estatal de Colorado en 2012 con una licenciatura en periodismo y comunicación técnica con especialización en ciencias políticas. Desde la universidad, Daniels ha desarrollado una carrera en torno a la amplificación de voces subrepresentadas. 

 

"It starts with the way that we talk with each other; that’s the foundation, and everything else builds from there.” 

"Comienza con la forma en que hablamos entre nosotros; esa es la base, y todo lo demás se construye a partir de ahí". 

 

Politico: <https://www.politico.com/staff/eugene-daniels>

fields.Research Focus: The Dean lab, of the Center for Vector-Borne Infectious Diseases (CVID), has a major focus on the development of a probiotic vaccine platform utilizing the probiotic organism Lactobacillus acidophilus. Specific applications include vaccines against human rotavirus, feline coronavirus (FECV) and SARS-CoV-2. We study the host mucosal immune response and immune mechanisms of multiple adjuvant strategies. The relationship between the host microbiome and mucosal immunity and the impact of oral vaccination on the intestinal microbiome are also active areas of research. Study of the immunpathogenesis of viral infections is an overarching emphasis.

fields.Primary Story Content: Many species of wildlife have been adversely impacted, or even have gone extinct, due to climate change. Polar bears, however, have become the poster species, as the effects of climate change are the most pronounced in the Arctic due to rapidly melting sea ice. Colleen Duncan, a veterinary pathologist at CSU, studies infectious disease and population dynamics in wildlife, and works with wildlife researchers at the U.S. Geological Survey and the U.S. Department of Agriculture to collect biological samples and health data from polar bears in northernmost Alaska.

fields.Primary Story Content:
Fields of Expertise
Data, GIS, and Modeling, Ecology, Ecosystem Dynamics, Education and Outreach

Areas of Interest
Ecosystem services, Invasive species, Mountain ecology

Biography
Dr. Paul Evangelista is a Research Ecologist at the Natural Resource Ecology Laboratory (NREL) and Assistant Professor in the Department of Ecosystem Science and Sustainability. His research at the NREL has extended across a broad array of interests, including invasive species, forestry, rare and endangered wildlife, ecosystem services, fire ecology, and climate change. His interests are frequently examined in the context of space and time through a suite of integrative spatial modeling techniques that combine field data, traditional and expert knowledge, geographic information systems (GIS), remote sensing and spatial statistics. Such analytical approaches have been used for early detection of invasive species, discovery of new wildlife populations, mapping land-cover and critical habitats, and predicting species’ distribution in response to changing climates. Dr. Evangelista’s research spans a wide breadth of ecosystems, including semi-arid canyon lands of the American Southwest, coniferous forests of the Rocky Mountains, Afro-alpine communities of Ethiopia’s highlands, and marine systems of the Atlantic Ocean. His research is regularly coupled with non-traditional educational programs that aim to build capacity through experiential learning, applied science and stakeholder engagement. This is best demonstrated by his advisory role with the DEVELOP Program, part of NASA’s Applied Science Program, hosted by the NREL and the US Geological Survey. Ultimately, Dr. Evangelista’s broad research interests center on supporting sustainable management, stewardship and conservation of natural resources.

fields.Primary Story Content: For pastoral people in East Africa, daily life revolves around the herd of animals that sustain them — and the land they travel to make sure the animals have room to graze and grow. As the climate changes, their traditional lifestyles are also changing, from subsistence to greater reliance on local villages for food, health care, and other services. CSU Anthropologist Kathleen Galvin has spent 30 years learning from the people who populate East African savannas. Listening to the Maasai share knowledge of climate change and the challenges it creates in their daily lives, Galvin also brings them together in a conversation with scientists and civil leaders to better understand the real human impacts of climate change on this vulnerable population.

fields.Primary Story Content:
Representing Coloradoans | Representar a los habitantes de Colorado 

From Yuma to the White House  | De Yuma a la Casa Blanca 

Corey Gardner was an U.S. American politician who represented Colorado in the U.S. Senate from 2015 to 2021. Prior to joining the senate, he served in the U.S. House of Representatives from 2011 to 2015.   

Corey Gardner fue un político estadounidense que representó a Colorado en el Senado de los EE. UU. de 2015 a 2021. Antes de unirse al Senado, sirvió en la Cámara de Representantes de los EE. UU. de 2011 a 2015. 

 

Gardner was born in Yuma, Colorado, a farm town in the northeastern part of the state, where his family owned a farm-machinery business. After graduating from Colorado State University in 1997 with a degree in political science, he earned a law degree from the University of Colorado in 2001.  

Gardner nació en Yuma, Colorado, un pueblo agrícola en la parte noreste del estado, donde su familia era propietaria de un negocio de maquinaria agrícola. Después de graduarse de la Universidad Estatal de Colorado en 1997 con una licenciatura en ciencias políticas, obtuvo una licenciatura en derecho de la Universidad de Colorado en 2001. 

 

After college, Gardner worked as a spokesperson for the National Corn Growers Association in Washington, D.C. In 2002 he began his political career by serving as legal counsel and later legislative director to U.S. Sen. Wayne Allard.   

Después de la universidad, Gardner trabajó como vocero de la Asociación Nacional de Cultivadores de Maíz en Washington, D.C. En 2002 comenzó su carrera política sirviendo como asesor legal y luego como director legislativo del senador estadounidense Wayne Allard. 

 

In 2005 Gardner was appointed to the Colorado House of Representatives, and he was elected to a full term the following year. He showed special interest in legislation concerning energy, with a focus on both renewable energy and fossil fuels.   

En 2005, Gardner fue designado miembro de la Cámara de Representantes de Colorado y fue elegido para un mandato completo al año siguiente. Mostró especial interés por la legislación en materia energética, con especial atención tanto a las energías renovables como a los combustibles fósiles. 

 

In 2010 Gardner was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives. After taking office the following year, he advocated for legislation furthering energy development. In 2014 he ran for the U.S. Senate Gardner won the election, and he took office in 2015.   

En 2010, Gardner fue elegido miembro de la Cámara de Representantes de los Estados Unidos. Después de asumir el cargo al año siguiente, abogó por una legislación que fomentara el desarrollo energético. En 2014 se postuló para el Senado de los Estados Unidos. Gardner ganó las elecciones y asumió el cargo en 2015. 

 

“The political science department at CSU has had a great impact on me. Many of the lessons I learned then, still apply today.” 

“El departamento de ciencias políticas de CSU ha tenido un gran impacto en mí. Muchas de las lecciones que aprendí entonces, todavía se aplican hoy”. 

 

<https://www.britannica.com/biography/Cory-Gardner>

fields.Primary Story Content:
Barnstorming Basketball | Baloncesto arrollador 

Becky Hammon has broken down barriers in the Basketball world  | Becky Hammon ha derribado barreras en el mundo del baloncesto. 

  

Becky Hammon   

 

Becky Hammon has barnstormed her way through the basketball world. She did it as a player at Colorado State University and in the WNBA, going from an undrafted hopeful to a six-time All-Star named to the league's 15th, 20th, and 25th Anniversary teams. As a coach, she became the NBA's first female assistant coach, and as she moved to the WNBA this season, she was named the Coach of the Year after the regular season, then led the Las Vegas Aces to their first WNBA title.  

Becky Hammon se ha abierto camino en el mundo del baloncesto. Lo hizo como jugadora en la Universidad Estatal de Colorado y en la WNBA, pasando de ser una aspirante no reclutada a ser nombrada All-Star seis veces y parte de los equipos del 15.°, 20.° y 25.° aniversario de la liga. Como entrenadora, se convirtió en la primera entrenadora asistente de la NBA y, cuando se mudó a la WNBA esta temporada, fue nombrada Entrenadora del Año después de la temporada regular y luego llevó a Las Vegas Aces a su primer título de la WNBA. 
 

Colorado Sportswoman of the Year 

All-American Becky Hammon played college basketball at Colorado State University, where she was an All-American player in the 1998-99 season and was named Colorado Sportswoman of the Year. She was Western Athletic Conference player of the year that season and led her team to the Sweet 16 at the NCAA Tournament. CSU retired her jersey in 2005, and she was inducted into the Colorado State Sports Hall of Fame in 2004.   

Deportista del año en Colorado 

All-American Becky Hammon jugó baloncesto universitario en la Universidad Estatal de Colorado, donde fue jugadora All-American en la temporada 1998-99 y fue nombrada Deportista del Año de Colorado. Fue la Jugadora del Año de la Conferencia Atlética Occidental esa temporada y llevó a su equipo a los Sweet 16 en el Torneo de la NCAA. CSU retiró su camiseta en 2005 y fue incluida en el Salón de la Fama del Deporte del Estado de Colorado en 2004. 

National Basketball Player  

After college, Hammon joined the Women's National Basketball League (WNBA) playing through the 2014 season as a point guard and later becoming one of the great players in the league. She played with the New York Liberty, the Tennessee Fury and Colorado Chill in the National Women's Basketball League (NWBL), and eventually played with the San Antonio Silver Stars. During her WNBA career, Hammon was a first-team All-WNBA selection in 2009 and was the seventh WNBA player to score 5,000 points, surpassing that milestone in 2011.   

Baloncestista Nacional 

Después de la universidad, Hammon se unió a la Liga Nacional de Baloncesto Femenino (WNBA) jugando durante la temporada 2014 como base y luego convirtiéndose en una de las grandes jugadoras de la liga. Jugó con New York Liberty, Tennessee Fury y Colorado Chill en la National Women's Basketball League (NWBL), y finalmente jugó con San Antonio Silver Stars. Durante su carrera en la WNBA, Hammon fue seleccionada en el primer equipo All-WNBA en 2009 y fue la séptima jugadora de la WNBA en anotar 5000 puntos, superando ese hito en 2011. 

Playing Overseas  

Hammon also played overseas in Italy in her off-seasons. In 2007 she received Russian citizenship and eventually played for Russia in the Olympics at the 2008 and 2012 Olympic Games.    

Jugar en el extranjero 

Hammon también jugó en el extranjero en Italia en sus temporadas bajas. En 2007 recibió la ciudadanía rusa y finalmente jugó para Rusia en los Juegos Olímpicos de 2008 y 2012. 

First female assistant coach in the NBA 
While playing in San Antonio, Hammon began attending practices with the BA San Antonio Spurs and was mentored by Spurs' coach Gregg Popovich. In August 2014, Hammon made history when Popovich asked her to become a full-time assistant coach for the Spurs after she retired at the end of the season. She thus became the first female to be a fully recognized assistant coach in the NBA.   

Primera entrenadora asistente en la NBA  

Mientras jugaba con San Antonio, Hammon comenzó a asistir a prácticas con los BA San Antonio Spurs y fue asesorada por el entrenador de los Spurs, Gregg Popovich. En agosto de 2014, Hammon hizo historia cuando Popovich le pidió que se convirtiera en entrenadora asistente de tiempo completo para los Spurs después de que ella se retirara al final de la temporada. Se convirtió así en la primera mujer en ser entrenadora asistente totalmente reconocida en la NBA. 

Rewarded for hard work  

In July 2015, she was the Spurs team coach in the NBA Summer League and led them to the title, becoming the first woman head coach of an NBA team.  She is now the head coach of the Las Vegas Aces of the WNBA. "It's just really awesome to be rewarded for all your hard work; that people take notice of how I treated my teammates, how I was in my community," Hammon said in an interview with ESPN.  

Recompensada por el trabajo duro 

En julio de 2015, fue entrenadora del equipo de los Spurs en la NBA Summer League y los llevó al título, convirtiéndose en la primera mujer entrenadora en jefe de un equipo de la NBA. Ahora es la entrenadora en jefe de Las Vegas Aces de la WNBA. "Es realmente increíble ser recompensada por todo tu arduo trabajo; que la gente se dé cuenta de cómo traté a mis compañeros de equipo, cómo era en mi comunidad", dijo Hammon en una entrevista con ESPN. 

"Playing basketball for me is like breathing."  

 "Jugar al baloncesto para mí es como respirar". 

<https://olympics.com/en/athletes/becky-hammon>     

<https://olympics.com/en/news/basketball-becky-hammon-becomes-first-woman-coach-in-the-nba>      

<https://www.espn.com/wnba/story/_/id/16428931/qa-san-antonio-spurs-assistant-coach-becky-hammon>   

<https://csurams.com/news/2022/9/20/ramwire-impact-50-hammons-trailblazing-rooted-at-colorado-state>

fields.Primary Story Content:
A trailblazer for education | Una pionera de la educación 


Educational Pathway:  

Bachelor of Science in Home Economics, Master of Education, Ph.D. in Educational Administration from Colorado State University.  

Educación: 

Licenciatura en Ciencias en Economía Doméstica, Maestría en Educación, Ph.D. en Administración Educativa de la Universidad Estatal de Colorado. 

A Trailblazer  

Dorothy Ortner Horrell is a trailblazer, educator, and community builder. She has dedicated her career to empowering individuals, organizations, and institutions to achieve their full potential. Currently she serves as Chancellor of the University of Colorado Denver.  

Una pionera 

Dorothy Ortner Horrell es una pionera, educadora y constructora de comunidades. Ha dedicado su carrera a empoderar a individuos, organizaciones e instituciones para que alcancen su máximo potencial. Actualmente se desempeña como Canciller de la Universidad de Colorado Denver. 

Discovering her life purpose 

Horrell, grew up on a farm near Holyoke, Colo. and is one of eight children.   

“The farm taught us that it was important to step up and do whatever it took to make things possible—for ourselves and others.  We all had chores and because there was lots to do, we each found those things we enjoyed and were good at.  I believe it was at that time I began to discover my life purpose.” 

Descubrimiento del propósito de su vida 

Horrell creció en una granja cerca de Holyoke, Colorado, y es una de ocho hijos. 

“La granja nos enseñó que era importante dar un paso adelante y hacer lo que fuera necesario para que las cosas fueran posibles, para nosotros y para los demás. Todos teníamos quehaceres y como había mucho que hacer, cada uno de nosotros encontraba aquellas cosas que disfrutaba y en las que era bueno. Creo que fue en ese momento cuando comencé a descubrir el propósito de mi vida”. 

Education as the Instrument of Hope  

“My parents set high expectations, and always emphasized the importance of education. They instilled in us the desire to learn, and we understood that education was our pathway to the future." 

Horrell sees education as the instrument of hope. She says, “It changes lives, not just for this generation but for generations to follow.”  

La educación como instrumento de la esperanza 

“Mis padres establecieron altas expectativas y siempre enfatizaron la importancia de la educación. Nos inculcaron el deseo de aprender y entendimos que la educación era nuestro camino hacia el futuro". 

Horrell ve la educación como el instrumento de la esperanza. Ella dice: "Cambia vidas, no solo para esta generación sino para las generaciones venideras". 

Lifechanging time abroad  

Shortly after graduating with her bachelor's degree, she was one of two students from Colorado selected to participate in a six-month International Farm Youth Exchange program in Taiwan arranged by 4-H. Her visit to Taiwan coincided with a typhoon, and she witnessed the resiliency and coping mechanisms of people affected by the storm. She later credited her International Farm Youth Exchange experience for developing her views on leadership and community. 

“It was eye-opening, and the first situation in my life where I experienced being very different from everyone else. It instilled in me the idea that none of us has “the right way” of doing things, and we shouldn’t judge those who are different as better, worse or wrong. It taught me how we all make choices about what matters, and we can get too focused on stuff.” 

Tiempo formativo en el extranjero 

Poco después de graduarse con su licenciatura, fue una de los dos estudiantes de Colorado seleccionados para participar en un programa de Intercambio Internacional de Jóvenes Agrícolas de seis meses en Taiwán organizado por 4-H. Su visita a Taiwán coincidió con un tifón y fue testigo de la resiliencia y los mecanismos de afrontamiento de las personas afectadas por la tormenta. Más tarde acreditó su experiencia en el Intercambio Internacional de Jóvenes Agrícolas por desarrollar sus puntos de vista sobre el liderazgo y la comunidad. 

“Fue revelador y la primera situación en mi vida en la que experimenté ser muy diferente a los demás. Me inculcó la idea de que ninguno de nosotros tiene “la forma correcta” de hacer las cosas, y no debemos juzgar a los que son diferentes como mejores, peores o incorrectos. Me enseñó cómo todos tomamos decisiones sobre lo que importa, y cómo podemos concentrarnos demasiado en las cosas”. 

Extensive Community Involvement  

Her extensive community involvement includes serving on boards for organizations focused on education, homelessness, and women’s leadership, as well as hospital systems, banking institutions, and economic development entities.  

Amplia participación en la comunidad 

Su amplia participación en la comunidad incluye servir en juntas directivas de organizaciones centradas en la educación, la falta de vivienda y el liderazgo de mujeres, así como en sistemas hospitalarios, instituciones bancarias y entidades de desarrollo económico. 

Numerous Honors  

Horrell’s numerous honors include the Colorado Women’s Chamber of Commerce Top 25 Most Powerful Women, the 2016 ATHENA leadership award, the Colorado 4-H Hall of Fame, and the  Colorado Women’s Hall of Fame. 

Numerosos honores 

Los numerosos honores de Horrell incluyen las 25 mujeres más poderosas de la Cámara de Comercio de Mujeres de Colorado, el premio de liderazgo ATHENA 2016, el Salón de la Fama 4-H de Colorado y el Salón de la Fama de Mujeres de Colorado. 

“Each of us has something special to offer and honoring that makes a lot of things possible. This is at the root of my belief system, and it’s how I try to operate as a leader.”  

“Cada uno de nosotros tiene algo especial que ofrecer y honrar que hace posible muchas cosas. Esta es la raíz de mi sistema de creencias, y así es como trato de operar como líder”. 

 

Links: <https://www.denver7.com/about/community-affairs/dorothy-horrell-colorado-womens-hall-of-fame-class-of-2018>

fields.Primary Story Content:
From Basketball to Comedy | Del baloncesto a la comedia 

Comedian and CSU Alumna Leslie Jones rose to fame as a cast member of 'Saturday Night Live' | La comediante y ex alumna de CSU Leslie Jones saltó a la fama como miembro del elenco de 'Saturday Night Live' 


Educational Pathway: Communications  
Educación: Comunicaciones 


“Funniest Person on Campus”  

After playing basketball in high school, Leslie Jones received a basketball scholarship from Chapman University in Orange, California. She then transferred to Colorado State University to play basketball. CSU was where she discovered a knack for stand-up comedy when a friend secretly entered her into an on-campus comedy contest. After winning the contest, she won the title "Funniest Person on Campus." 

“As soon as I touched the mic, I knew that's what I would do for the rest of my life.” 

“La persona más cómica del campus” 

Después de jugar baloncesto en la escuela secundaria, Leslie Jones recibió una beca de baloncesto de la Universidad de Chapman en Orange, California. Luego se transfirió a la Universidad Estatal de Colorado para jugar baloncesto. CSU fue donde descubrió una habilidad especial para la comedia stand-up cuando un amigo la inscribió en secreto en un concurso de comedia en el campus. Después de ganar el concurso, ganó el título de "Persona más cómica del campus". 

“Tan pronto como toqué el micrófono, supe que eso sería lo que haría por el resto de mi vida”. 

 

Saturday Night Live  

After several years on the comedy circuit, Jones joined Saturday Night Live as a writer in 2014, and soon became one of the show's most popular performers.  

Saturday Night Live 

Después de varios años en el circuito de la comedia, Jones se unió a Saturday Night Live como escritora en 2014 y pronto se convirtió en una de los artistas más populares del programa. 

 

Acting in Popular Films  

She has appeared in films like Trainwreck, the Ghostbusters reboot, and Masterminds.  

Actuar en películas populares 

Ha aparecido en películas como Trainwreck, el reinicio de Ghostbusters y Masterminds. 

 

Time’s Most Influential People  

Jones is so accomplished that she was named one of Time's 100 most influential people in the world in 2017. 

Las personas más influyentes de la revista Time 

Jones tiene tantos logros que fue nombrada una de las 100 personas más influyentes del mundo de Time en 2017. 

 

Hosting “Supermarket Sweep” 

After leaving "Saturday Night Live," in 2019 Jones became the host of "Supermarket Sweep”, the revival of her favorite game show from the 1980s.  

Presentadora de “Supermarket Sweep” 

Después de dejar Saturday Night Live en 2019, Jones se convirtió en la presentadora de "Supermarket Sweep", el renacimiento de su programa de juegos favorito de la década de 1980. 

 

“My job is to bring the tickle. I know what's funny.” 

“Mi trabajo es traer las cosquillas. Sé lo que es gracioso”.

fields.Primary Story Content:
Pulitzer Prize-winning “solider poet” and “Jazz poet” | Ganador del premio Pulitzer "poeta soldado" y "poeta de jazz" 

Komunyakaa is one of the most popular and influential American writers and poets of his generation | Komunyakaa es uno de los escritores y poetas estadounidenses más populares e influyentes de su generación. 

Educational Pathway: Master of Arts 1978 

Educación: Maestría en Artes 1978 

Civil Rights and Vietnam War 

Yusef Komunyakaa was born on April 29, 1947, in Bogalusa, Louisiana, where he was raised during the beginning of the Civil Rights Movement. He served a tour of Army duty during the Vietnam War and was a journalist for the military paper covering action, interviewing fellow soldiers, and publishing articles on Vietnamese history and literature. Upon his return to the states, he turned to poetry, eventually becoming one of the most popular and influential American writers of his generation.  

Los derechos civiles y la guerra de Vietnam 

Yusef Komunyakaa nació el 29 de abril de 1947 en Bogalusa, Louisiana, donde se crió durante el comienzo del Movimiento por los Derechos Civiles. Cumplió un período de servicio en el ejército durante la guerra de Vietnam y fue periodista para el periódico militar que cubría la acción, entrevistaba a compañeros soldados y publicaba artículos sobre historia y literatura vietnamita. A su regreso a los Estados Unidos, se dedicó a la poesía y finalmente se convirtió en uno de los escritores estadounidenses más populares e influyentes de su generación. 

Master of the Arts 

Komunyakaa began writing poetry in 1973 and received his bachelor’s degree from the University of Colorado Springs in 1975. His first book of poems, Dedications & Other Darkhorses, was published in 1977, followed by Lost in the Bonewheel Factory in 1979. During this time, he earned his MA and MFA in creative writing from Colorado State University in Fort Collins and the University of California, Irvine, respectively. 

Maestro de las artes 

Komunyakaa comenzó a escribir poesía en 1973 y recibió su licenciatura de la Universidad de Colorado Springs en 1975. Su primer poemario, Dedications & Other Darkhorses, se publicó en 1977, seguido de Lost in the Bonewheel Factory en 1979. Durante este tiempo, obtuvo su maestría y maestría en escritura creativa de la Universidad Estatal de Colorado en Fort Collins y la Universidad de California, Irvine, respectivamente. 

Becoming a “Jazz Poet”  

Komunyakaa first received wide recognition following the 1984 publication of Copacetic, a collection of poems built from colloquial speech demonstrating his incorporation of jazz influences. He followed the book with two others: I Apologize for the Eyes in My Head published in 1986, winner of the San Francisco Poetry Center Award; and Dien Cai Dau, published two years later, which won The Dark Room Poetry Prize and has been cited by poets, such as William Matthews and Robert Hass, as being among the best writing on the war in Vietnam. 

Convertirse en un "poeta de jazz" 

Komunyakaa recibió por primera vez un amplio reconocimiento tras la publicación en 1984 de Copacetic, una colección de poemas construidos a partir del habla coloquial que demuestra su incorporación de influencias del jazz. Siguió el libro con dos más: I Apologize for the Eyes in My Head publicado en 1986, ganador del Premio del Centro de Poesía de San Francisco; y Dien Cai Dau, publicado dos años después, que ganó el premio de poesía The Dark Room y ha sido citado por poetas, como William Matthews y Robert Hass, como uno de los mejores poemarios escritos sobre la guerra de Vietnam. 

Pulitzer Prize winner 

Since then, Komunyakaa has published several books of poems, including The Emperor of Water Clocks and Thieves of Paradise, which was a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award; Neon Vernacular: New & Selected Poems for which he received the Pulitzer Prize and the Kingsley Tufts Poetry Award; and Magic City. 

Ganador del premio Pulitzer 

Desde entonces, Komunyakaa ha publicado varios libros de poemas, incluidos The Emperor of Water Clocks y Thieves of Paradise, que fue finalista del Premio del Círculo Nacional de Críticos de Libros; Neon Vernacular: New & Selected Poems por la que recibió el premio Pulitzer y el premio de poesía Kingsley Tufts; y Magic City. 

Dramatic works  

Komunyakaa’s writing is collected in Blues Notes: Essays, Interviews & Commentaries. He also coedited The Jazz Poetry Anthology, co-translated The Insomnia of Fire by Nguyen Quang Thieu, and served as guest editor for The Best of American Poetry 2003. He has also written dramatic works, including Gilgamesh: A Verse Play, and Slip Knot, a libretto in collaboration with Composer T. J. Anderson, commissioned by Northwestern University. 

Obras dramáticas 

Los escritos de Komunyakaa se recopilan en Blues Notes: Essays, Interviews & Commentaries. También coeditó The Jazz Poetry Anthology, cotradujo The Insomnia of Fire de Nguyen Quang Thieu y se desempeñó como editor invitado de The Best of American Poetry 2003. También ha escrito obras dramáticas, que incluyen Gilgamesh: A Verse Play y Slip Knot, un libreto en colaboración con el compositor T. J. Anderson, encargado por la Universidad Northwestern. 

Additional honors  

Komunyakaa is the recipient of the 2011 Wallace Stevens Award. His other honors include the Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize, The Griffin Poetry Prize Lifetime Recognition Award, the William Faulkner Prize from the Université de Rennes, the Thomas Forcade Award, the Hanes Poetry Prize, fellowships from the Fine Arts Work Center in Provincetown, the Louisiana Arts Council, and the National Endowment for the Arts. 

Honores adicionales 

Komunyakaa recibió el Premio Wallace Stevens 2011. Sus otros honores incluyen el Premio de Poesía Ruth Lilly, el Premio de Reconocimiento a la Vida del Premio de Poesía Griffin, el Premio William Faulkner de la Université de Rennes, el Premio Thomas Forcade, el Premio de Poesía Hanes, becas del Centro de Trabajo de Bellas Artes en Provincetown, el Consejo de las Artes Louisiana y el Fondo Nacional de las Artes. 

Sharing wisdom through education  

Komunyakaa was elected Chancellor of the Academy of American Poets in 1999. He has taught at the University of New Orleans, Indiana University, as a professor in the Council of Humanities and the creative writing program at Princeton University. He lives in New York City, where he is currently a distinguished senior poet in New York University’s graduate creative writing program. 

Compartir la sabiduría a través de la educación 

Komunyakaa fue elegido Canciller de la Academia de Poetas Estadounidenses en 1999. Ha enseñado en la Universidad de Nueva Orleans, Universidad de Indiana, como profesor en el Consejo de Humanidades y en el programa de escritura creativa de la Universidad de Princeton. Vive en la ciudad de Nueva York, donde actualmente es un distinguido poeta senior en el programa de posgrado de escritura creativa de la Universidad de Nueva York. 

Poet Toi Derricotte wrote for the Kenyon Review, “He takes on the most complex moral issues, the most harrowing ugly subjects of our American life. His voice, whether it embodies the specific experiences of a black man, a soldier in Vietnam, or a child in Bogalusa, Louisiana, is universal. It shows us in ever deeper ways what it is to be human.” 

El poeta Toi Derricotte escribió para la Kenyon Review: “Aborda las cuestiones morales más complejas, los temas feos más angustiosos de nuestra vida estadounidense. Su voz, ya sea que encarne las experiencias específicas de un hombre negro, un soldado en Vietnam o un niño en Bogalusa, Louisiana, es universal. Nos muestra de maneras cada vez más profundas lo que es ser humano”. 

 

<https://poets.org/poet/yusef-komunyakaa>

fields.Primary Story Content: Sometimes referred to coloquially as "zombie deer disease," chronic wasting disease (CWD) is a prion disease affecting deer, elk, reindeer, and moose. While the exact mechanisms aren't fully understood, prions -- misfolded proteins -- cause neurons to degenerate by forming plaques in the central nervous system. As neurons die, holes are formed in the brain and other neural tissue, leading to dramatic weight loss, listlessness, trouble walking, and eventually death. While there has never been a reported case of CWD in humans, a jump to humans is not outside of the realm of possibility. And humans already experience other protein-misfolding diseases such as Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, and diabetes. CSU's Candace Mathiason is a leading researcher in the area of prions -- while working on her Ph.D., she demonstrated for the first time that prions are carried in bodily fluids and can be transmitted without direct bodily contact -- and hopes that her research into mechanisms of transmission can shed light on not just CWD, but a wide range of neurodegenerative diseases.

fields.Primary Story Content:
A Hot Breakfast for Cattle | Un desayuno caliente para el ganado 

A CSU Scientist Made Better Beef Available Worldwide |  

Un científico de CSU hizo una mejor carne disponible en todo el mundo 

Johnnie Matsushima, Professor of Animal Science at Colorado State University 

Educational Pathway: 1943 Bachelor’s in Animal Science 

1945 Master’s in Animal Science 


Johnnie Matsushima, profesor de ciencias animales en la Universidad Estatal de Colorado 

Trayectoria Educativa: 1943 Licenciatura en Ciencias Animales  

1945 Maestría en Ciencias Animales 


Kiichiro “Johnnie” Matsushima solved a worldwide problem while eating a bowl of oatmeal. His hot breakfast made him imagine a way to give cattle a “hot breakfast” of their own that was easier for them to digest and required significantly less grain. 

Kiichiro “Johnnie” Matsushima resolvió un problema mundial mientras comía un bol de avena. Su desayuno caliente le hizo imaginar una manera de darle al ganado un "desayuno caliente" propio que fuera más fácil de digerir y requiriera significativamente menos grano. 

A More Nutritious Diet 

Cattle don’t have upper teeth they need to chew grain, so he noticed their manure (“poop”) was full of undigested grains that their bodies couldn’t use for nutrition.  

He used steam and mechanical pressure to turn corn kernels into flakes for cattle feed. This revolutionary invention made it easier and more affordable to produce high-quality beef. With his “hot breakfast,” Matsushima transformed the world’s cattle industry and made better beef available all over the world. 

Una dieta más nutritiva 

El ganado no tiene los dientes superiores que necesitan para masticar granos, por lo que notó que su estiércol ("caca") estaba lleno de granos sin digerir que sus cuerpos no podían usar para nutrirse. 

Usó vapor y presión mecánica para convertir los granos de maíz en hojuelas para alimentar al ganado. Este invento revolucionario hizo que fuera más fácil y asequible producir carne de res de alta calidad. Con su “desayuno caliente”, Matsushima transformó la industria ganadera mundial e hizo que la mejor carne estuviera disponible en todo el mundo. 

A Colorado Childhood 

Johnnie Matsushima grew up feeding his family’s cows and horses in Lafayette and Platteville, Colorado. The oldest of seven children whose parents emigrated to the U.S. from Japan, he joined 4-H and Future Farmers of America and graduated as the valedictorian of Platteville High. He was a student at CSU during World War II, when Japanese-Americans faced rampant discrimination. After he earned a Ph.D. at the University of Minnesota, he came back to CSU to be a professor and expert in feedlot nutrition.  

Una infancia en Colorado 

Johnnie Matsushima creció alimentando a las vacas y los caballos de su familia en Lafayette y Platteville, Colorado. El mayor de siete hijos cuyos padres emigraron a los EE. UU. desde Japón, se unió al 4-H y Future Farmers of America y se graduó como el mejor alumno de Platteville High. Fue estudiante de la CSU durante la Segunda Guerra Mundial, cuando los japoneses-estadounidenses enfrentaron una discriminación desenfrenada. Después de obtener un doctorado en la Universidad de Minnesota, regresó a CSU para ser profesor y experto en nutrición de corrales de engorde. 

A Lifetime of Invention 

This was one of many inventions Matsushima devised during a career in which he helped lead the modernization and expansion of U.S. and global beef production with scientific advances and data-based decision making. His work helped propel Colorado’s industry into the nation’s top 5, while he also helped advance the industries in Africa, Italy, Australia, Canada, China and Japan. 

In 2011, the Emperor of Japan presented him with his country’s highest civilian honor, the Tennbo Hosho (Emperor Citation) for his scientific advances in feeding the world. 

Una vida de invenciones 

Este fue uno de los muchos inventos que ideó Matsushima durante una carrera en la que ayudó a liderar la modernización y expansión de la producción de carne de res en los EE. UU. y en el mundo con avances científicos y toma de decisiones basada en datos. Su trabajo ayudó a impulsar la industria de Colorado a ser entre las mejores cinco de la nación, mientras que también ayudó a impulsar las industrias en África, Italia, Australia, Canadá, China y Japón. 

En 2011, el Emperador de Japón le otorgó el más alto honor civil de su país, el Tennbo Hosho (Mención del Emperador) por sus avances científicos en la alimentación del mundo. 

“John Matsushima is a living legend. Honestly, he changed things forever in the world. He is one of the most important people in the history of the livestock industry.” – Paul Andrews, CEO and president, National Western Stock Show, quoted in The Fort Collins Coloradoan, 2017 

“John Matsushima es una leyenda viva. Honestamente, cambió las cosas para siempre en el mundo. Es una de las personas más importantes en la historia de la industria ganadera”. – Paul Andrews, CEO y presidente, National Western Stock Show, citado en The Fort Collins Coloradoan, 2017

fields.Research Focus: Steven Miller received his BSc in Electrical and Computer Engineering from U.C. San Diego (1995), and MS (1997) and PhD (2000) in Atmospheric Science from Colorado State University. His areas of interest include satellite-based remote sensing of the Earth/atmosphere system from a wide assortment of sensor technologies including active/passive systems spanning the optical to microwave portions of the electromagnetic spectrum. From 2000 to 2007, he worked at the Naval Research Laboratory in Monterey, CA in the Satellite Meteorological Applications Section, where he developed numerous value-added satellite imagery tools for operational users (including mineral dust, snow cover, cloud optical properties, low cloud/fog, fire, thin cirrus, deep convection, natural color, contrail, volcanic ash, and nighttime low-light applications). His mineral dust detection algorithms for MODIS and SeaWiFS were among the first to exploit blue-band absorption properties. In 2005, Dr. Miller published the first satellite detection of a widespread bioluminescence phenomenon (the ‘Milky Sea’) using the DSMP Operational Linescan System.  This was followed in 2021 by new detections by the next-generation Day/Night Band low-light sensor. Dr. Miller joined CIRA in 2007 as a Research Scientist and Deputy Director. In 2021 he joined the Faculty of CSU’s Department of Atmospheric Science, where he serves as Professor and Director of CIRA.  He continues work in developing satellite techniques geared toward operational end-users.

fields.Primary Story Content:
California Wine Pioneer  | Pionero del vino de California 

A Construction Management graduate transformed the U.S. wine industry  | Un graduado de Administración de la Construcción transformó la industria del vino estadounidense. 

Joseph Phelps 

Educational Pathway: Bachelor’s degree in Construction Management						Military service in the Navy during the Korean War 

Ruta educativa: Licenciatura en Administración de la Construcción Servicio militar en la Armada durante la Guerra de Corea 

A Love for Building  

Even before graduating from Colorado State University, Joseph Phelps had earned quite a bit of work experience – as a newspaper carrier, print shop owner, filling station attendant, fishing lure purveyor, surveyor, and estimator. But he first made his mark in construction, building the Colorado company his father founded during the Great Depression, Hensel Phelps Construction, into one of the largest and most successful construction companies in the U.S.  

While working on construction projects in Napa Valley, California, he began to learn about wine-making. In 1973, he converted a California cattle ranch into Joseph Phelps Vineyards. He became one of California’s most influential leaders in the wine industry. 

Un amor por la construcción 

Incluso antes de graduarse de la Universidad Estatal de Colorado, Joseph Phelps había adquirido bastante experiencia laboral: como repartidor de periódicos, dueño de una imprenta, empleado de una gasolinera, proveedor de señuelos de pesca, topógrafo y tasador. Pero primero dejó su huella en la construcción, al convertir la compañía de Colorado que su padre fundó durante la Gran Depresión, Hensel Phelps Construction, en una de las compañías de construcción más grandes y exitosas de los EE. UU. 

Mientras trabajaba en proyectos de construcción en Napa Valley, California, comenzó a aprender sobre la elaboración del vino. En 1973, convirtió un rancho de ganado de California en Joseph Phelps Vineyards. Se convirtió en uno de los líderes más influyentes de California en la industria del vino.

Hard Work and Innovation

Between the winery and his construction business, Joe Phelps worked 14-hour days, learning  everything he could about grape growing and winemaking. He surrounded himself with experts, experimented constantly and applied what he’d learned to producing wines that could be counted among the finest in the world.  

“He molded not just the styles and flavors of Napa Valley wines, but also the ways the industry has grown, treated its workers, managed its land, and cultivated its grapes.” – Patrick J. Comiskey, the San Francisco Chronicle, 2003 

Trabajo duro e innovación 

Entre la bodega y su negocio de construcción, Joe Phelps trabajaba 14 horas al día, aprendiendo todo lo que podía sobre el cultivo de la uva y la vinificación. Se rodeó de expertos, experimentó constantemente y aplicó lo aprendido para producir vinos que podrían contarse entre los mejores del mundo. 

“Él moldeó no solo los estilos y sabores de los vinos del Valle de Napa, sino también las formas en que la industria ha crecido, trató a sus trabajadores, administró su tierra y cultivó sus uvas”. – Patrick J. Comiskey, San Francisco Chronicle, 2003 


He sold Hensel Phelps Construction to its employees in 1986, and he always credited his years there for much of the success he found in the wine business. It taught him the lesson that would stay with him, and that he practiced, throughout his life: that success should be shared, and can only come with a team of motivated people working toward the same goal.  

“Known as a low-key yet influential leader, Phelps was one of California’s most innovative vintners.” – Wine Spectator

Vendió Hensel Phelps Construction a sus empleados en 1986, y siempre atribuyó gran parte del éxito que encontró en el negocio del vino a sus años allí. Le enseñó la lección que se quedaría con él y que practicó a lo largo de su vida: que el éxito debe ser compartido y solo puede venir con un equipo de personas motivadas que trabajan hacia la misma meta. 

“Conocido como un líder discreto pero influyente, Phelps fue uno de los vinicultores más innovadores de California”. – Espectador del vino 

He had a lasting impact in both the construction and wine industries – and on Colorado State University, where he donated money to help hire and retain top construction management faculty and support student internships. He also created a memorial garden at CSU in honor of his brother, John.  

Tuvo un impacto duradero tanto en la industria de la construcción como en la del vino, y en la Universidad Estatal de Colorado, donde donó dinero para ayudar a contratar y retener a los mejores profesores de administración de la construcción y apoyar las pasantías de los estudiantes. También creó un jardín conmemorativo en CSU en honor a su hermano, John. 


 “When people say, ‘How did you get into the wine business from the construction business, I always say, ‘One sip at a time.’” – Joe Phelps 


"Cuando la gente dice: '¿Cómo llegaste al negocio del vino desde el negocio de la construcción?, siempre digo: 'Un sorbo a la vez'". - Joe Phelps 

 

Sources: 

<https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/21/us/joseph-phelps-dies-at-87-brought-innovation-to-california-wines.html> 

<https://www.josephphelps.com/joe/>  

<https://www.provencewinezine.com/on-the-passing-of-joseph-phelps-1927-2015/> 

<https://www.sfgate.com/wine/article/The-steward-of-Napa-Valley-Joseph-Phelps-2680931.php>

fields.Primary Story Content: CSU Professor Robin Reid works with people in Kenya, Mongolia, and Colorado, applying science to help them address issues that matter most to their communities. A professor in the Department of Ecosystem Science and Sustainability, Reid heads CSU's Center for Collaborative Conservation. She spent 20 years in East Africa, where she developed a process of continuous engagement among landowners, communities, nongovernmental organizations, government, and scientists to address issues ranging from elephant poaching in Africa to wildfire mitigation in the American West.
