fields.Primary Story Content:
A Clean Energy Economy 

Una economía de energía limpia 

Facilitating a just and equitable transition to clean energy 

Facilitar una transición justa y equitativa hacia la energía limpia 

 

Energy Communities in Transition 

Comunidades energéticas en transición 

 

The energy sector in the U.S. and around the globe is in transition. Coal plants are shutting down earlier than expected. There has been an 18% annual decline in the number of producing coal mines from 2019 and a 62% decline since 2008. These mines are being replaced by cleaner and less expensive energy sources like renewables (wind and solar) and natural gas. 

El sector energético en los EE. UU. y en todo el mundo está en transición. Las plantas de carbón están cerrando antes de lo esperado. Ha habido una disminución anual del 18 % en la cantidad de minas de carbón en producción desde 2019 y una disminución del 62 % desde 2008. Estas minas están siendo reemplazadas por fuentes de energía más limpias y menos costosas, como las energías renovables (eólica y solar) y el gas natural. 

Communities home to coal mines and coal plants rely on the jobs and revenue provided by the industry, and with closures face uncertain futures. Founded by Colorado’s 41st Governor, Bill Ritter, Jr., The Center for the New Energy Economy (CNEE) is working with coal community members and policymakers to help support community-led, equitable transitions from coal to a cleaner and more sustainable economy. 

Las comunidades que albergan minas y plantas de carbón dependen de los empleos y los ingresos que proporciona la industria, y con los cierres se enfrentan a un futuro incierto. Fundado por el gobernador 41 de Colorado, Bill Ritter, Jr., el Centro para la Nueva Economía Energética (CNEE) está trabajando con miembros de la comunidad del carbón y legisladores para ayudar a apoyar transiciones equitativas y dirigidas por la comunidad del carbón a una economía más limpia y sostenible. 

 

Connecting energy policy leaders and experts 

Conectar a los líderes y expertos en políticas energéticas 

 

The CNEE convenes policymakers and facilitates dialogue among stakeholders. It creates and maintains free, publicly available tools and resources, and publishes energy policy research. For example, the State Policy Opportunity Tracker (SPOT) serves as a hub of information on both existing state clean energy policies and, uniquely, future policy opportunities. 

La CNEE convoca a los formuladores de políticas y facilita el diálogo entre las partes interesadas. Crea y mantiene herramientas y recursos gratuitos y disponibles públicamente, y publica investigaciones sobre políticas energéticas. Por ejemplo, el Rastreador de Oportunidades de Políticas Estatales (SPOT) sirve como un centro de información tanto sobre las políticas estatales existentes de energía limpia como, únicamente, las oportunidades de políticas futuras. 

An alum powering forward 

Un ex alumno impulsado hacia adelante 

 

Governor Bill Ritter was elected Colorado’s 41st Governor in 2006 and was the District Attorney of Denver from 1993-2005. During his four-year term as Governor, Ritter established Colorado as a national and international leader in clean energy by building a New Energy Economy. Ritter earned his bachelor’s degree in political science from Colorado State University  in 1978 and his law degree from the University of Colorado in 1981.  After leaving the Governor’s Office, Ritter founded the Center for the New Energy Economy at Colorado State University, which works with state and federal policymakers to create clean energy policy throughout the country. 

El gobernador Bill Ritter fue elegido gobernador número 41 de Colorado en 2006 y fue fiscal del distrito de Denver de 1993 a 2005. Durante su mandato de cuatro años como gobernador, Ritter estableció a Colorado como líder nacional e internacional en la energía limpia mediante la construcción de una nueva economía energética. Ritter obtuvo su licenciatura en ciencias políticas de la Universidad Estatal de Colorado en 1978 y su título de abogado de la Universidad de Colorado en 1981. Después de dejar la Oficina del Gobernador, Ritter fundó el Centro para la Economía de la Nueva Energía en la Universidad Estatal de Colorado, que trabaja con legisladores estatales y federales para crear una política de energía limpia en todo el país. 

 

“For me, the New Energy Economy has always been about our future, our kids’ future, our grand kids’ future. I think to survive in this created space we inhabit, we need to produce and consume energy differently. If we do not then our legacy for our children will be a Colorado inferior to the Colorado that we live in.” – Colorado’s 41st Governor, Bill Ritter, Jr., Director of the Center for the New Energy Economy, Colorado State University 

 

“Para mí, la Economía de la Nueva Energía siempre se ha tratado de nuestro futuro, el futuro de nuestros hijos, el futuro de nuestros nietos. Creo que para sobrevivir en este espacio creado que habitamos, necesitamos producir y consumir energía de manera diferente. Si no lo hacemos, nuestro legado para nuestros hijos será un Colorado inferior al Colorado en el que vivimos”. – Gobernador número 41 de Colorado, Bill Ritter, Jr., Director del Centro para la Economía de la Nueva Energía, Universidad Estatal de Colorado

fields.Primary Story Content:
Connecting Landscapes | Conectar paisajes 

Accelerating the pace and scale of North American Conservation | Acelerar el ritmo y la escala de la conservación en América del Norte 

 

The Rio Grande Runs Through It 

Growing up on a farm in the San Luis Valley, Ken Salazar spoke only Spanish at home. The place he called home is a vast valley that extends from the Continental Divide on the northwest into New Mexico on the south. It is a spectacular high elevation valley home to potato farmers and Great Sand Dunes National Park. Ceded to the United States by Mexico following the Mexican–American War, Hispanic settlers moved north and settled the valley after a treaty was made between the US and the Utes. It is against this backdrop where former U.S. Senator and now current U.S. Ambassador to Mexico Salazar began realizing his vision for connecting large landscapes and people. 

El Río Grande lo atraviesa 

Al crecer en una granja en el Valle de San Luis, Ken Salazar solo hablaba español en casa. El lugar al que llamó hogar es un vasto valle que se extiende desde la división continental en el noroeste hasta Nuevo México en el sur. Es un espectacular valle de gran altura que alberga agricultores de patatas y el Parque Nacional Great Sand Dunes. Cedido a los Estados Unidos por México después de la Guerra México-Estadounidense, los colonos hispanos se mudaron al norte y se asentaron en el valle después de que se firmó un tratado entre los Estados Unidos y los Utes. Fue en este contexto donde el exsenador de los EE. UU. y ahora actual embajador de los EE. UU. en México, Salazar, comenzó a realizar su visión de conectar grandes paisajes y personas. 

 

A Center for Conservation Is Born 

Having experienced first-hand the connections between large landscapes and people, between communities and a river that flows through communities and across artificial boundaries, and between cultures and the lands they form relationships with, Ken Salazar knew the importance of healthy and resilient natural landscapes and human communities. He brought this knowledge to his role as 50th U.S. Secretary of the Interior, U.S. Senator, and Colorado Attorney General and transformed it into action, creating new many new National Parks and co-founding the Salazar Center for North American Conservation. 

The Center hosts an annual international symposium on conservation impact which convenes leaders from throughout the continent to explore major conservation challenges. Alongside the symposium, the Center offers an annual incentive challenge. 

Nace un centro para la conservación 

Por experimentar de primera mano las conexiones entre los grandes paisajes y las personas, entre las comunidades y un río que fluye a través de las comunidades y a través de límites artificiales, y entre las culturas y las tierras con las que se relacionan, Ken Salazar sabía la importancia de los paisajes naturales saludables y resilientes y las comunidades humanas. Aportó este conocimiento a su función como Secretario del Interior número 50 de los EE. UU., Senador de los EE. UU. y Fiscal General de Colorado y lo transformó en acción, creando muchos parques nacionales nuevos y co-fundando el Centro Salazar para la Conservación de América del Norte. 

El Centro organiza un simposio internacional anual sobre el impacto de la conservación que convoca a líderes de todo el continente para explorar los principales desafíos de la conservación. Junto con el simposio, el Centro ofrece un desafío de incentivo anual. 

Finding Common Ground 

It is Salazar’s hope that with the country more polarized than ever, Americans can find common ground on the most pressing environmental problems — climate change, land use, water quality and quantity — and that the Center can bring together diverse ideas and people. 

“I think the area of conservation, how we protect our lands, our air and our water, can be a great unifier for a very divided world and a very divided nation,” said Salazar. 

Encontrar un terreno común 

Es la esperanza de Salazar que con el país más polarizado que nunca, los estadounidenses puedan encontrar puntos en común sobre los problemas ambientales más apremiantes (cambio climático, uso de la tierra, calidad y cantidad del agua) y que el Centro pueda reunir ideas y personas diversas. 

“Creo que el área de conservación, cómo protegemos nuestras tierras, nuestro aire y nuestra agua, puede ser un gran unificador para un mundo muy dividido y una nación muy dividida”, dijo Salazar. 

 

“Growing up in a very rural and remote area in Colorado's San Luis Valley - one of the poorest counties in the United States - essentially created the framework of values from which I operate – Ken Salazar” 

“Crecer en un área muy rural y remota en el Valle de San Luis de Colorado, uno de los condados más pobres de los Estados Unidos, esencialmente creó el marco de valores desde el cual opero – Ken Salazar”

fields.Research Focus: Enviro Justice, Uranium Mining - Navajo Nation
fields.Primary Story Content: In 1979, toxic and radioactive material from the Church Rock uranium mill in Northwest New Mexico spilled into the Puerco River and made its way onto the Navajo Nation, whose people were not alerted of the spill’s toxic dangers until days later. It was not until 2008, however, that Congress authorized a five-year cleanup plan for the affected area. Dr. Gilbert John, a CSU microbiologist and member of the Navajo Nation, works to study and better understand the health issues and psychological impacts of the uranium disaster on the Navajo people, who used the river's water for drinking, irrigation, and livestock. John also actively empowers young Native students to pursue careers in STEM disciplines.

fields.Primary Story Content: In developing countries like Ecuador, as populations shift from rural to urban areas, diets often shift from traditional, grain- and vegetable-based fare to a more Western diet, high in sugar and fat. Professor Chris Melby with the Colorado School of Public Health at CSU studies how nutrition — and lack of access to diverse, healthy, nutritious foods — contributes to the chances of having a life-changing illness like stroke, heart disease, or diabetes. Melby is working with colleagues and graduate students in Ecuador to study how to help communities navigate this "nutrition transition," maximizing dietary diversity and minimizing risks for malnutrition and obesity.

fields.Primary Story Content:
Gentle Relentlessness 

Una inquietud suave 

From First Generation to Vice President 

De primera generación a vicepresidenta 

Mary Ontiveros 

 

"She never gave up trying to improve the place and the people" - Tony Frank 

"Ella nunca dejó de intentar mejorar el lugar y la gente" - Tony Frank 

Mary Ontiveros came to CSU as a first-generation college student in 1969. A humble woman, she likely never imagined serving in so many leadership roles nor culminating her career as CSU Vice President for Diversity. “Nobody had seen the scope of change at CSU that she had,” Frank said. 

Mary Ontiveros llegó a CSU como estudiante universitaria de primera generación en 1969. Una mujer humilde, probablemente nunca imaginó desempeñar tantos roles de liderazgo ni culminar su carrera como vicepresidenta de diversidad de CSU. “Nadie había visto el alcance del cambio en CSU que ella tenía”, dijo Frank. 

 

Persistence led to diverse experiences which led to immense impacts 

La persistencia la llevó a diversas experiencias que llevaron a inmensos impactos. 

Born and raised one of six children, she credited her parents for her drive and work ethic. They insisted she go to college but lacked the funds to cover costs. "You do what you have to do, right? I would go all around campus asking for different jobs, so I came to know the university quite a bit.” These experiences and her relentless pursuit of inclusivity and access to higher education for all left a legacy. 

Nacida y criada como una de seis hijos, le dio crédito a sus padres por su empuje y ética de trabajo. Insistieron en que fuera a la universidad, pero carecían de los fondos para cubrir los costos. “Haces lo que tienes que hacer, ¿verdad? Iba por todo el campus pidiendo diferentes trabajos, así que llegué a conocer bastante la universidad”. Estas experiencias y su incansable búsqueda de la inclusión y el acceso a la educación superior para todos dejaron un legado. 

 

Helping CSU become a more just and equitable community 

Ayudar a CSU a convertirse en una comunidad más justa y equitativa 

 

Mary went on to earn her BS in Psychology. Following her graduation, Ontiveros started a long career at CSU, starting out as a research associate in 1974 and working her way up to from an administrative assistant in the Chicano Studies Office to acting director of Chicano Student Services and then to associate director of admissions, associate vice president for enrollment and access, and ultimately vice president of diversity. 

Mary obtuvo su BS en Psicología. Después de su graduación, Ontiveros empezó una larga carrera en CSU, comenzando como investigadora asociada en 1974 y ascendiendo desde asistente administrativa en la Oficina de Estudios Chicanos hasta directora provisional de Chicano Student Services y luego directora asociada de admisiones, vicepresidenta asociada de inscripción y acceso y, en última instancia, vicepresidenta de diversidad. 

Every step of the way, she used her knowledge gained over half a century’s worth at CSU to provide perspective on how the university got to where it was, where it is headed and what that means for students of all races, ethnicities, and socio-economic statuses. From having to add a letter to an Asian student's two-letter first name to be able to be entered into enrollment systems to being told "told the university is not ready to have two Latinx women in a leadership position in the same office" the legacy she left will be a changed University that must continue its journey towards become more diverse, just, equitable, and inclusive. 

En cada paso del camino, utilizó su conocimiento adquirido durante medio siglo en CSU para brindar una perspectiva sobre cómo la universidad llegó a donde estaba, hacia dónde se dirigía y qué significa eso para los estudiantes de todas las razas, etnias y estados socioeconómicos. Desde tener que agregar una letra al nombre de dos letras de un estudiante asiático para poder ingresar en los sistemas de inscripción hasta que le dijeran que "la universidad no está lista para tener dos mujeres latinx en una posición de liderazgo en la misma oficina" el legado que dejó será una universidad cambiada que debe continuar su camino hacia ser más diversa, justa, equitativa e incluyente. 

 

“She made CSU a better place through her presence and that quiet, yet relentless commitment. … I’m proud to have worked alongside her, proud to call her my friend, and am a better human being for knowing her.” - Tony Frank 

“Ella hizo de CSU un mejor lugar a través de su presencia y ese compromiso silencioso pero implacable. … Estoy orgulloso de haber trabajado junto a ella, orgulloso de llamarla mi amiga y soy un mejor ser humano por conocerla”. -Tony Frank

fields.Research Focus: Kenya: Leads food initiative at Rockefeller in Nairobi
fields.Primary Story Content:
Transforming Food Systems | Transformar los sistemas alimentarios 

Transforming the fresh produce markets in Africa | Transformación de los mercados de productos frescos en África 

 

Educational Pathway:   

Bachelor of Science, Agribusiness Management, Egerton University 

Master of Science, Agricultural and Resource Economics, Colorado State University 

Educación: 

Licenciatura en Ciencias, Gestión de Agronegocios, Universidad de Egerton 

Maestría en Ciencias, Economía Agrícola y de Recursos, Universidad Estatal de Colorado 

 

Smart Food Markets  

Betty Kibaara is a Director in the Food Initiative at The Rockefeller Foundation, Africa Region Office. At the Foundation, Betty leads investments in transforming food systems, specifically investments in innovations on smart food markets for the future, increasing access to nutritious foods through instructional procurement. She is also advancing insect-based feed for improved nutrition.  

Mercados de alimentos inteligentes 

Betty Kibaara es Directora de la Iniciativa Alimentaria en la Oficina de la Región de África de la Fundación Rockefeller. En la Fundación, Betty lidera inversiones en la transformación de los sistemas alimentarios, específicamente inversiones en innovaciones en mercados de alimentos inteligentes para el futuro, aumentando el acceso a alimentos nutritivos a través de la adquisición instructiva. También está promoviendo alimentos a base de insectos para mejorar la nutrición. 

Improving Farmer Livelihood  

Kibaara led the implementation of the YieldWise Initiative to reduce food loss in Corn in Tanzania, Mangoes in Kenya, and Cassava and Tomato value chains to improve livelihoods for the smallholder farmers in Africa.  

Mejorar el sustento de los agricultores 

Kibaara lideró la implementación de la iniciativa YieldWise para reducir la pérdida de maíz en Tanzania, mangos en Kenia y  cadenas de valor de yuca y tomate para mejorar la vida de los pequeños agricultores en África. 

Transforming Produce Markets in Africa  

Kibaara believes that there is no food system transformation without transforming the fresh produce markets in Africa. She serves as the regional champion for the Rockefeller Foundation’s initiatives in strengthening food security, agribusiness, and resilience to the devastating effects of climate change to enable real, sustainable, and equitable economic growth.  

Transformar los mercados de productos agrícolas en África 

Kibaara cree que no hay transformación del sistema alimentario sin transformar los mercados de productos frescos en África. Se desempeña como defensora regional de las iniciativas de la Fundación Rockefeller para fortalecer la seguridad alimentaria, los agronegocios y la resiliencia a los efectos devastadores del cambio climático para permitir un crecimiento económico real, sostenible y equitativo. 

Educational Background  

Before joining the Rockefeller Foundation in 2009, Kibaara worked as a Research Fellow at the Tegemeo Institute of Agricultural Policy and Development, Egerton University. She holds a Master of Science degree in Agricultural and Resource Economics from Colorado State University and a Bachelor of Science in Agribusiness Management from Egerton University in Kenya. 

Formación educativa 

Antes de unirse a la Fundación Rockefeller en 2009, Kibaara trabajó como investigadora en el Instituto Tegemeo de Política y Desarrollo Agrícola de la Universidad de Egerton. Tiene una Maestría en Ciencias en Economía Agrícola y de Recursos de la Universidad Estatal de Colorado y una Licenciatura en Ciencias en Gestión de Agronegocios de la Universidad de Egerton en Kenia.

fields.Primary Story Content:
Say hi to strangers 

The first thing you notice about Colorado State University custodian Robert Serunjogi is that he’s very outgoing and friendly 

Saludar a los desconocidos 

Lo primero que se nota sobre el conserje de la Universidad Estatal de Colorado, Robert Serunjogi, es que es muy extrovertido y amigable. 

 

A friendship is born 

A conversation Robert Serunjogi struck up with a complete stranger more than four years ago not only blossomed into a friendship, but a fundraising campaign that generated almost $70,000 to build schools for orphans in his home country of Uganda. 

“I say ‘Hi’ to a lot of strangers, and this time it paid off” he says. “I got that from my grandmother. She’d say that if you don’t say ‘How are you?’ how are you going to make friends?” 

Laura Schreck was a CSU graduate student at the time Robert said hello. She started a GoFundMe campaign after hearing from him about the need to raise money to build schools in his home village in Uganda. 

Nace una amistad 

Una conversación que Robert Serunjogi entabló con un desconocido hace más de cuatro años no solo se convirtió en una amistad, sino en una campaña de recaudación de fondos que generó casi $70,000 para construir escuelas para huérfanos en su país de origen, Uganda. 

"Digo 'Hola' a muchos extraños, y esta vez valió la pena", dice. “Eso lo heredé de mi abuela. Ella decía que si no dices '¿Cómo estás?' ¿Cómo vas a hacer amigos?” 

Laura Schreck era una estudiante de posgrado de CSU en el momento en que Robert la saludó. Ella comenzó una campaña de GoFundMe después de escuchar de él sobre la necesidad de recaudar dinero para construir escuelas en su pueblo natal en Uganda. 

 

Role of Education 

Ultimately, Serunjogi — who juggles a job at McDonald’s with his custodial work at the University — wants to return to Uganda and work as a teacher. “For me, education is very important, because if everyone had access to education, the world would be safer,” he says. “The community can benefit from you if you get a good education.” 

And Serunjogi, who earned his bachelor’s degree in political science from CSU, adds that education opens doors as well - just as it has for Laura who graduated with an MS in Health and Exercise Science in May 2019. 

“Having an education gives you the power to be independent,” he says. “I want that for the children of my village.” 

El papel de la educación 

En última instancia, Serunjogi, que tiene que balancear un trabajo en McDonald's con su trabajo de custodia en la Universidad, quiere regresar a Uganda y trabajar como maestro. “Para mí la educación es muy importante, porque si todos tuvieran acceso a la educación, el mundo sería más seguro”, dice. “La comunidad puede beneficiarse de ti si obtienes una buena educación”. 

Y Serunjogi, quien obtuvo su licenciatura en ciencias políticas de CSU, agrega que la educación también abre puertas, tal como lo hizo para Laura, quien se graduó con una maestría en ciencias de la salud y el ejercicio en mayo de 2019. 

“Tener una educación te da el poder de ser independiente”, dice. “Quiero eso para los niños de mi pueblo”. 

 

Making an Impact 

The buildings serve as schools, health clinics and dorms for about 180 children between the ages of 4 and 14. 

“Now we have buildings with roofs,” Serunjogi says. “When it rains, we don’t have to interrupt class to get under a tree." 

Schreck had the opportunity to visit and brought with her CSU's Little Shop of Physics crew. Jones, director of the Little Shop of Physics and an instructor in the Department of Physics, and Ferguson, an LSOP teacher in residence, brought 750 pounds of science education materials in more than 20 suitcases that they left at Serunjogi’s village after introducing their curriculum to students and teachers alike. 

“We’re putting resources into a well-run organization,” Jones said. 

Schreck says Serunjogi’s friends and relatives in the very family-oriented, community-centric village were worried about whether he had found a good community in the United States. “People would say, ‘Thank you for taking care of Robert,’” Schreck says. “They were glad to meet his community in the U.S., and we would tell them, ‘Thank you for letting us take care of him and letting us have Robert in our lives.’” 

Tener un impacto 

Los edificios sirven como escuelas, clínicas de salud y dormitorios para unos 180 niños de entre 4 y 14 años. 

“Ahora tenemos edificios con techos”, dice Serunjogi. “Cuando llueve, no tenemos que interrumpir la clase para meternos debajo de un árbol”. 

Schreck tuvo la oportunidad de visitar y trajo consigo el equipo Little Shop of Physics de CSU. Jones, director del equipo Little Shop of Physics e instructor en el Departamento de Física, y Ferguson, maestro residente de LSOP, trajeron 750 libras de materiales de educación científica en más de 20 maletas que dejaron en el pueblo de Serunjogi después de presentar su plan de estudios a estudiantes y profesores. 

“Estamos poniendo recursos en una organización bien administrada”, dijo Jones. 

Schreck dice que los amigos y parientes de Serunjogi en el pueblo centrado en la comunidad y orientado a la familia estaban preocupados por si había encontrado una buena comunidad en los Estados Unidos. "La gente decía: 'Gracias por cuidar de Robert'", dice Schreck. “Estaban contentos de conocer a su comunidad en los EE. UU., y les decíamos: ‘Gracias por permitirnos cuidarlo y permitirnos tener a Robert en nuestras vidas'”. 

 

“Having an education gives you the power to be independent” - Robert Serunjogi 

“Tener una educación te da el poder de ser independiente” - Robert Serunjogi

fields.Research Focus: LiDAR/Archaeology - Mexico, Central and South America
fields.Primary Story Content: In Honduras, a previously hidden ancient city came to light when archaeologist and CSU professor Chris Fisher used LiDAR technology to look under the dense tree canopy and undergrowth of the jungle. Fisher’s groundbreaking, or really ground-viewing, use of LiDAR has changed the face of modern archaeology, speeding discovery by radically shortening the time it takes to “uncover” previously undiscovered sites. Ultimately, Fisher’s research expeditions in the jungles of Honduras and Mexico aim to help us better understand the causes and consequences of urbanism and environmental change.

Dr. Ramesh Akkina is a professor of Microbiology, Immunology, and Pathology at Colorado State University, Fort Collins, USA. 

A PhD from the University of Minnesota, Minneapolis, he did his post-doctoral work and was a visiting professor at the UCLA School of Medicine, Los Angeles. 

He is a leading researcher in the HIV field and made many ground breaking discoveries in viral infectious diseases. His early contributions were in Influenza virology and stem-cell based gene therapy strategies. His lab pioneered in work with humanized mice with a transplanted human immune system for HIV and Dengue virus research as well as for delivery of novel gene therapy molecules. 

Recent work developed new pre-exposure prophylaxis methods to prevent HIV transmission, successfully tested anti-HIV si-RNAs and aptamers and showed that immune exhaustion during HIV infection can be partly reversed by PD-1 blockade. 

Ongoing work is centered on HIV latency, prevention, novel therapeutics and viral evolution. His research is supported by multiple NIH grants. He is a member of many editorial and international grant review boards. He is currently the Center Director for Global Virus Network at Colorado State University and Chair of the NIH AIDS ADDT grant review study section.

fields.Research Focus: Dr. Mahmoud’s research program has three major thrusts. The first thrust pertains to spatial and temporal quantification of community resilience subjected to extreme natural hazards including wildfires, tornados, hurricanes, flooding, and earthquakes. The second thrust is focused on assessment and development of resilient and sustainable infrastructure systems subjected to natural and man-made hazards including single and multi-hazards such as blast, fire, earthquakes, and wind or the combination of such. The third major thrust pertains to assessment, evaluation, and repair of deteriorated infrastructure subjected to high and low-cycle fatigue. He has conducted various studies on fatigue evaluation and he has performed numerous in-service assessment of major structures across the U.S. that resulted in the development of proto-type retrofits that have successfully been implemented and adopted by various design specifications.

fields.Primary Story Content: As a fully online, asynchronous university, Colorado State University Global lives up to its name. Since its inception, the university has graduated students from over 60 countries across the globe and every state and territory in the United States. Beginning in 2007, CSU Global was the first 100% online, accredited, nonprofit state university in the U.S. and has since become a leader in delivering industry-relevant programs for nontraditional learners. Because there are no set class times and coursework can be completed from any location–coupled with 24/7 1:1 tutoring services, library access, and IT support–CSU Global is accessible to students anywhere in the world who are looking to advance their careers. _(Include visual pins to demonstrate each country with CSU Global students)._
fields.Spatial Angle: Global Impact - History of CSU Global
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Woman working at a laptop computer leaning to her side and hugging a young child.

fields.Primary Story Content:
Committed to teaching students up-to-date, relevant professional skills, all CSU Global faculty are required to have recent industry experience and many remain active in their field. One of CSU Global’s prominent faculty members, Criminal Justice Program Director Dr. J. Michael Skiba, is a prime example as an international leading expert on financial and cyber crime. Trademarking the name “Dr. Fraud,” with over 25 years of experience in special investigations, Dr. Skiba has operated in over 96 countries and is regularly called upon by top agencies in the world to assist with fraud prevention, such as the United Nations, the FBI, and the CIA. Earlier this year, Dr. Skiba partnered with the Coalition Against Insurance Fraud and led a team of researchers to measure the annual cost of insurance fraud in the U.S.--which came out to $309 billion–a figure that has not been calculated since 1995. Dr. Skiba travels on a regular basis sharing his expertise and speaking at the world’s leading fraud conferences.

As a recent example, in August 2022, Dr. Skiba traveled to Thailand with the United Nations, where he worked with all of the military, police, and VIPs (political, etc.)]to train them on the threats from cybercrime and fraud. The below picture features Dr. Skiba in the middle surrounded by Thailand's most elite police unit--the Thailand Royal Police, and also members from the UN, Interpol and Europol.
fields.Spatial Angle: Thailand

fields.Primary Story Content: Alumna Deirdre Jonker’s time as a CSU Global student can be quantified in “twos” — two continents and two degrees. Jonker is a dual citizen of the U.S. and the Netherlands, and she has graduated with her Bachelor’s in Criminal Justice and Master’s in Information Technology Management. With the skills she gained during her education, Jonker set out to develop an app. She looked into how people suffer from addictions and behavior related to the use (or misuse) of pharmaceuticals and wanted to provide an alternative that would help people mentally, physically, and financially. In 2020, she participated in the Google Developers Console and developed Comspeare, a free app that releases 40Hz GAVA waves to help users relax during stressful times and reduce anxiety with sound. The app published in the Google Play Store and the Apple App Store in 2021. Today, Jonker lives in Amsterdam, promoting Comspeare and reaching out to medical and health care institutions to see if the app could benefit their patients.
fields.Spatial Angle: The Netherlands
fields.Story Card Image Alt Text: Woman wearing headphones and closed eyes and softly smiling
fields.Hometown: Dual citizen of the U.S. and the Netherlands

fields.Primary Story Content: CSU Global’s flexible course structure, dedicated military benefits team, military friendliness academic policy, and military-affiliated tuition discounts have earned it the rank of no. 6 in the nation for Best Online Programs for Veterans according to U.S. News & World Report. The university is not only home to many active-duty service members and veterans, but their family members as well. Alumna Kirsten Hackett, a military spouse, sought an online program while she was living in Japan, where her husband was deployed. “Being in another time zone on a different continent, I knew I wouldn’t be able to be in class at a set time,” Hackett said. The ability to pause coursework at CSU Global also appealed to her, as students may take a break for up to 12 months and still remain in good academic standing. That option can help accommodate the unpredictable life of a military spouse; for instance, in the event of a move. Kirsten earned her B.S. in Marketing and is currently putting the skills she learned in her degree program to use as Senior Social Media Strategist at Stealth Creative. Even though she needed to move to another country when her husband deployed, Kirsten did not have to put her own professional aspirations on hold. She was able to earn her degree while living oversees and land the career of her dreams upon returning to the U.S.
fields.Spatial Angle: Kirsten lived in Japan when she started her program at CSU Global, and she currently lives in St. Louis, MO, where she works as a senior social media strategist.

fields.Primary Story Content:
It's impossible to know if a seed is alive or dead without the testing done by seed labs.  That's pretty incredible for something that has so much significance and influence on the survival of humans and animals.  
For the farmers and gardeners who produce the food we rely on, or conservationists who are reclaiming land that has been damaged, seed analysts and seed labs they work in, are the glue that holds the seed industry and agriculture as whole, together.  The Seed Industry accounts for nearly 22 million jobs in the United States, this includes seed analysts and labs they work in like the Colorado Seed Lab.  The Colorado Seed Lab has been operating at Colorado State University in Fort Collins for over 100 years.
Seed labs find out how vigorously a seed will grow by testing its germination.  How vigorously will the seed one plants germinate?  100% of them, 20% of them, or none?  Farmers, gardeners and conservationists need to know how many seeds will germinate before they plant them.  Seed analysts also look at what else may be in that bag.  Are there seeds from weeds or other crop plants in that bag of seeds to be planted?  Some of those extra or unwanted seeds, may produce noxious weeds or unwanted crops.  Seed analysts can identify what plant a seed will become without seeing the actual plant, a pretty rare skill for botanists!   Most plant identification is done by looking at the whole plant.  Seed labs give all this information to the people or companies selling seed.  All seed sellers and distributors have to put the information the lab gives them (germination and purity of the seed lot) on a label that is attached to the container of seed before its distributed.  That way the consumer can determine if they want to buy and plant that bag of seed or not.  
Seed has moved all around the world for centuries.  No matter where the seed was grown, the companies or people distributing and receiving that seed rely on testing done at a seed lab to know how healthy and vigorous that seed is.  The Colorado Seed Lab is proud to provide this vital information to both the seed industry and to consumers (those who plant seeds) locally and around the world.
Seeds grown in Colorado that produce grain, vegetables, fiber, and forage are exported all over the world.  Millet grain grown in Colorado is exported to countries like Indonesia, Australia, and New Zealand.  Beans grown in Colorado are exported to countries like Mexico.  Flower seeds produced in Colorado are exported to the European Union, Great Britan and countries like China.  Hemp seeds produced in Colorado are exported to countries like Uruguay, and other US states and territories including Puerto Rico.  Hard Red Winter Wheat is Colorado's top crop, grown on over 2 million acres in the state, all of which originates from seed.  75 to 80% of grain that is harvested from Colorado wheat fields is exported to other countries.  Mexico, Nigeria and Japan round out the top three.
fields.Spatial Angle: US and Colorado, however all seed labs follow similar international standards, and these labs exit all over the world. Seeds move all around the world.  Seed quality must be communicated to all receiving parties whether they be in other countries or the garden center or coop down the street.

fields.Third Grade Level Story:
Seeds are one of the most important ingredients for human survival.  Without seeds, the plants that provide our food, fuel, fiber, oxygen, and many other essential products would not exist.  
Good quality, strong seeds are needed for farmers and gardeners to grow the food we rely on, or for conservationists who are reclaiming land that has been damaged.  It's impossible to know if a seed is alive or dead without a Seed Lab and the Seed Analysts that work there.  They find out how strongly a seed will grow by testing its germination or the seed's ability to send out roots and form shoots. Seed germination can be somewhat mysterious because is usually occurs undergrounds where we can't see what's happening.
Farmers, gardeners and conservationists need to know how many seeds will germinate before they plant them.  Seed analysts also look at what else may be 'hiding' in the bag of seeds we plant.  Are there extra seeds from weeds or other crop plants in that bag of seeds to be planted?  Some of those extra or unwanted seeds, may produce noxious weeds or other crops that the farmer or land manager does not want.  Seed analysts have special skills, they can identify the plant that seed will become!   Seed labs give all this information to the people selling seed.  People selling seed have to put the information the lab gives them about germination and other weed or crops seeds on a label so farmers and gardeners can know what's in the bag.  That way the consumer can determine if they want to buy and plant that bag of seed or not.  
People move seed all over the world.  No matter where the seed was grown, the companies or people distributing and receiving that seed rely on testing done at a seed lab to know how healthy and strong that seed is.   Seed labs exist in every state of the U.S. and in every country around the world.  As well, the crops grown from seed in Colorado are exported to countries all over the world.
fields.Impactful Quote:
"Pretty much all agriculture starts with the seed.  Anything that ends up on your dinner plate, somehow seed is involved with that."  Randy Crowl, RST, Colorado Seed Lab Manger, CSU.

"I find our job really important because we are testing seed quality to feed the world."  Kaitlyn Fulmer, Biological Science Aide, USDA Gene Laboratory (National Laboratory for Genetic Preservation)

"Any seed sold in the world has to be tested" Richard Agnew, RST, Applewood Seed

"Without seeds, our food supply, clothing, buildings, beautiful scenery, soil stability, wildlife habitat, energy and other products vital to life would no longer be available."  Laura Pottorff, Director of Colorado Seed Programs, CSU
